NSSC-
NEWSLETTER
Vol. Ill, Number 2
May 1, 1955
Advisory Group Aids AFROTC Officials
The NSSC Advisory Committee to Hq, Air Force ROTC, met at Maxwell Air Force
Base, Alabama, on April 7-9, 1955, to serve as consultants on the revision of materials
for the Air Force ROTC Communication Course.
Pictured above are: (seated) Col. Henry Dittman, Chief of Staff, Hq, AFROTC;
Elwood Murray, Committee Chairman; Col. John Crosthwaite, Deputy Commandant,
Hq, AFROTC; John Keltner; Paul Bagwell; Col. D. W. Cox, Chief, Education Branch,
Hq, AFROTC. (standing) Ralph Nichols; Merle Ogle, Chief Educational Consultant,
Hq, AFROTC; Francis Cartier, Educational Specialist, Hq, AFROTC.
Harwood Plans Five
Convention Meetings
Plans are being made for five sec¬
tional meetings on communication
problems at the NSSC National Con¬
vention in Los Angeles in December,
1955, according to information re¬
ceived from Ken Harwood.
Section meetings and chairmen
are as follows: “Communication Dis¬
orders,” Herold Lillywhite; “Devel¬
opments in Information Theory and
Communication,” Elwood Murray;
“Literature as Communication,”
Ralph Allen; “Communication in
the Military Service,” Major Ed
Holder; and “Problems of Adult
Education and Communication in
Businss and Industry,” P. E. Lull.
The last section meeting named will
be sponsored jointly by NSSC and

this issue of the Newsletter is
the 1955 Directory of NSSC
Members. In addition to the
master list which is alphabeti¬
cally arranged and includes
name, address, occupation, spe¬
cial interests, type of member¬
ship, and years of membership,
the members are listed by state
or country, occupation, and
special interests.
A limited number of extra
copies of the insert are avail¬
able for 50c each from the Exe¬

Summer Conference
To be at Michigan
State August 26-29
The Third Annual Summer Con¬
ference of the National Society for
the Study of Communication will
be held August 26 to 29 at Butter¬
field Hall, Michigan State Univer¬
sity, East Lansing, Mich. All details
and arrangements for the conference
are being planned by the Central
Michigan Society for the Study of
Communication.
There will be no limit to housing
facilities available. The Continuing
Education Service will provide new
dormitory and Kellogg Center facili¬
ties for the use of those attending
the conference. Because the Con¬
tinuing Education Service will
handle meals and housing, those who
attend the conference will be able
to attend as many or as few of the
four days of the conference as they
choose without needing to pay hous¬
ing and meal costs for the entire
conference.
Families are wanted at the con¬
ference according to a recent com¬
munique from Russ Jenkins, chair¬
man of the Summer Conference
Committee. At least one session
will be devoted to communication
in the family. The housing facilities
are “good for families”, Jenkins em¬
phasized.
Committee chairmen for major
activities are: Publicity—Paul Bag-
well; Planning — Robert Starring;
Program — Russ Jenkins. Other
members of the program committee
are: Charles Irvin, Walker Hill,
Homer Scott, Louis Cherbeneau,
Alice Cherbeneau, Edgar DeForest,
and William A. Peterson.
Donald E. Bird is conducting a
survey of the listening activities and
problems of 200 hospital dietitians
for the American Dietetic Associa¬
tion. He will report the results of
the survey at the ADA national con¬
vention in St. Louis on October 18-
21, 1955.
